newsitem.title: SWITZERLAND: UN cautiously welcomes Zaire military airdrop plan.
newsitem.headline: UN cautiously welcomes Zaire military airdrop plan.

text.p: The United Nations refugee agency UNHCR on Wednesday cautiously welcomed Canada's proposal for a military airdrop of supplies to Rwandan refugees in east Zaire.
But UNHCR spokesman Fernando del Mundo said airdrops would still require a presence on the ground to ensure that supplies reached refugees in need instead of Hutu militiamen.

The U.N. High Commissioner for Refugees, Sadako Ogata, has repeatedly called for the deployment of a multi-national task force in east Zaire to help aid agencies gain access to an estimated 700,000 wandering refugees scattered in the region.
The return home of 500,000 Hutus has weakened support for that plan, vehemently opposed by Rwanda.

"We welcome any plan that would ease the suffering of these people," del Mundo said. "But an airdrop would depend on ground presence. It could be a last resort. There would still be a need to determine on the ground who the recipients are."
Canada, leading a planned U.N.-authorised military relief effort, has proposed parachuting food over Zaire from a base in neighbouring Uganda which lacks good road links with east Zaire.

U.S. Defence Secretary William Perry, visiting NATO's southern command in Naples, Italy, on Wednesday ruled out sending a U.S. combat force to Zaire but said Washington was ready to take part in the Canadian airdrop proposal.
Several countries have tentatively offered to take part in the military relief effort but have yet to decide the next step.
In recent years food supplies have been parachuted to Moslems in Bosnia and to Kurds in northern Iraq where some falling crates killed or injured civilians.
The Hutu refugees fled to east Zaire in fear of reprisal for a 1994 Hutu-led genocide of minority Tutsis after which a Tutsi-dominated army swept to power in Rwanda.
